title: DS330.08 Property Indexes | DataStax Enterprise 6 Graph
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS330
DS330.08 Property Indexes
In this unit, you will learn about property indexes in DataStax Enterprise Graph. These are a type of vertex-centric indexes, and are useful for vertices with multi- and meta-properties.

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] now that we've covered vertex or global indexes let's dive into property indexes which are a type of vertex centric indexes once we found a starting point with an id lookup or a vertex index lookup the only other index that can be used along gremlin's route is a vertex centric index which is a property or an edge index property indexes can be used to efficiently retrieve data from multi-properties with meta properties this is an example of a vertex centric index it's useful for multi-properties with meta properties and it can support equality and inequality predicates these property indexes are implemented with specialized materialized views in apache cassandra let's take a look at some examples from our killer video data set so for the first example we're looking for a budget estimate for a given movie we can see the schema creation for an index entitled movie budget by source for the multi-property budget by source which is a meta property an example of this is getting a movie with the movie id m267 and getting the budget whose source matches los angeles times for the second example we're going to index the movie budget estimates by date here we have an example of selecting movie m267 and we want to get the budget from the last 12 months we can take a look at what we've created with our property indexes by describing the schema first we can look at the full schema of the graph and you can do that in your studio notebook or we can look at the vertex label movie and see what we've created on that vertex we can see the partition key and the properties which we've seen before and then at the end we can see the two property indexes that we've created we can also drop these indexes as well let's take a look at how you do that for a vertex label movie we can specify the movie budget by source index and drop it and likewise for the movie budget by date index now that we've covered property indexes let's go back to the notebook and do an exercise
